p: Tataguine virus (TATV) takes its name from the village in Senegal where it was first isolated in 1962 from Anopheles and Culex species [ 56]. In 1966, it was also isolated in Cameroon from An. gambiae and from serum of a 14-year-old boy. The patient presented with fever, exanthema, asthenia, muscle aches, and neutropenia, and TATV was confirmed by inoculation in mice [ 56]. TATV was widespread in African countries surveyed from 1960 to 1970, including Nigeria, South Africa, and Ethiopia [ 103, 104].
